Sea Lyme Grass. Elymus arenarius. P.—
Lesser Field Scabious. S. columbaria. P.—
Little Field Madder. Sherardia arvenss. P.
Great Bastard Madder. G. Mollugo. P.—
Goose Grass: Clivers. Galium Aparine. A.—

89.Ladies Mantle, Dr. Haller, in his Iter Helveticum, tells us, that the astonishing richness of the milk in the famous dairies of the Alps, described by Scheuckzer, is attri∣buted entirely to the plenty of this plant, and that of the Ribwort Plantain.
Cinquefoil Ladies Mantle. A. alpina. P.—
Mouse-ear Scorpion Grass. Myosotis scorpi∣oides. a. P.—
Water Scorpion Grass. M. palustris. b.—
In corn fields, not very common. 8.
About hedges and bushes every where. 7.
About hedges, &c. in moist places about woods. 6, 7.
In pastures, and by the way sides. 6.
On the sea coast, not common. 5, 6.
In meadows, and by way sides. 4—8.
In meadows, and the borders of fields. 7.
On upland pastures in the North. 6—8.
In pastures, and about hedges and bushes. 5, 6.
By way sides every where; in pastures. 6, 7.
In meadows and pastures every where. 6, 8.
In gravelly ground, and on the sea coast. 7, 8.
95.Mouse-ear Scorpion Grass. Constantly refused by all these animals.

96.Water Scorpion Grass. This is considered as only a variety of the former, owing to its place of growth, which renders the plant larger in all its parts, and destroys the hairy∣ness of its leaves. It is common in watery places, and the sheep will sometimes eat it, in which case it is frequently fatal to them, as Linnaeus discovered in his Iter Gotlandicum.
By the road sides: dry pastures. 5, 6.
In lanes, and by road sides. 6.
Small wild Bugloss. Lycopsis arvensis. A.—
Primrose and Cowslip. Primula vulgaris. P.
Yellow Willow Herb. Lysimachia vulgaris. P.
Round-leaved Bell Flower. Campanula ro∣tundifolia. P.—

117.White Mullein, called also Cow's Lang-wort, from the great reputation it had for∣merly with our country people for inveterate coughs among the horned cattle. Parkinson tells us it was used in his time, in such cases, w th great success, and it yet retains the same credit in some parts of Europe. Gunner. Lorsel.
Great White Mullein. Verbascum Thapsus. B

125.Black Berry-bearing Alder. The bark of this tree is said to be the most certain purge for the horned cattle in obstinate constipations of the bowels. Lin. Gunner says, horses do not eat the leaves, but that cows sometimes will, and that it greatly increases the milk.
135.English Mercury. Common about Farm-yards. The country people give the root to their sheep in obstinate coughs. Lin.
Common English Mercury. Chenopodium Bonus Henricus. P.—
Goosesoot, or Sowbane. C. murale. A.—
In moist places and by river sides. 5—8.
In corn fields and fallow land. 6—9.
On fallow ground, and by way sides. 7, 8.
On boggy mountains in the North. 5.

In wet meadows, and about ditches. 6.
In corn fields, and on sandy places. 5—8.
In hedges, especially in moist places. 7, 8.

In hedges in the North, not common.
On the coast, in salt marshes. 7.

136.Goosefoot, or Sowbane. This has the character of being poisonous to swine; yet it appears that these animals will eat it. Almost all the old writers give it the character of a poisonous plant, and John Bauhine particularly avers, that it is so to these animals; as do also some of the more modern writers.
In cultivated places, and among corn. 8.
In waste places and cultivated spots. 8.
In like places with the foregoing, 8.
In waste places, and on dunghills, 8.

142.Marsh Pennywort. It does not appear that any experiments were made with this plant. It is very common in marshy grounds with us, and our farmers are of opinion that it gives sheep the rot, and thence call it White Rot. In this light Parkinson mentions it.
146.Cow Parsnip. The cows are known to be particularly fond of this plant; and Mr. Ray observes that the rabbits are no less so.
Great Water Parsnip. Sium latifolium. P.—

151.Common Water Hemlock. This plant is very common in England. It is a well∣known fact in Sweden, that horses will eat it, and that it frequently proves fatal to them by inducing a palsy: this effect, nevertheless, is judged to be owing to an insect, which inhabits in great plenty the stalks of this herb, and from this singular effect is called by LINNAEUS, Curculio paraplecticus, when in its perfect state, as the Larva only exists in this vegetable. The same caterpillar is found in the Water Parsnip also in England.

152.Long-leaved Water Hemlock. Happily this plant is not very common in England: the roots are the most virulent vegetable poison that is indigenous here. LINNAEUS, in the Flora Lapponica, No 103, gives a dreadful account of the havock it frequently made among the horned cattle in Lapland, where it is common in the meadows near the sea, and where these cattle will frequently eat it, upon being first turned to grass in the spring, though they afterwards refuse it: yet they will eat the roots at all times, which are the most virulent parts of the plant. Bishop Gunner and Gmelin both confirm these bad ef∣fects. It is yet doubtful whether horses are hurt by it; and certain that goats are de∣lighted with it, and eat it without any subsequent ill effect: and the roots are collected by the Norwegian peasants as fodder for those animals.
Wild Cicely, or Cow-weed. Charophyllum sylvestre. A.—
Herb Gerard: Gout-weed. Aegopodium Poda∣graria. P.—
Grass of Parnassus, Parnassia palustris. P.—
Thrist: Sea Gilliflower. Statice Armeria P.
Lilly of the Valley. Convallaria majalis.—
Common soft Rush. Juncus effusus. P.—
Common hairy Wood Rush. J. pilosus. P.—
Small hairy Wood Rush. J. campestris. P.
By hedges, and on the banks of ditches. 6, 7.
About hedges, rivers, and in pastures. 7.
In moist woods, in watery places. 6, 7.
In rivers, ponds, and marshy places. 7, 8.
In marshes, and in ditches, common. 7.
By the sides of rivers and brooks. 6, 7.
On the banks of rivers and ponds, &c. 7—9.
153.Fools Parsley. This is deleterious to the human race, although eaten by these quadrupeds.
In corn fields, and on banks of ditches. 8.
Hedges, waste places; among corn, every where. 5, 6.
With the former, every where: orchards. 7, 8.
In hedges, and often the pest of gardens. 6.
About waters, especially near the sea. 8.
In hedges by way sides, in church yards. 7.
On the sea coast, and with the foregoing.
Sun-dew. Sun-dew is called by the country people Red-rot, on account of its destructive quality to sheep. Ray.166.

169.Lancashire Aspbodel. This plant is also thought to be very noxious to sheep, when∣ever through poverty of pasture they are necessitated to eat it, although they are said to im∣prove much in their flesh at first, and afterwards to die with the symptoms of a diseased liver. This is the plant of which such wonderful tales have been told by Pauli, Bartho∣line, and others, of its softening the bones of such animals as are it; and which they thence called Gramen ossifragum. Horned cattle eat it without any ill effect. Gunner.
On boggy grounds, not very frequent. 8.
About the coast, and in salt marshes. 7.
In moist marshes and heaths, common. 8.
In gravelly soil, about standing waters. 7.
In dry turfy meadows and pastures. 4.
In and about rivers and lakes. 7, 8.
185.Sea spiked Grass. Cows are extremely fond of this grass; as indeed they are of many other maritime plants: and equally so of the foregoing species.
Sea spiked Grass. T. maritimum. P.—
Water Plantain. Alisma Plantago aquatica. P.
190.Common Heath, or Ling. The bees are thought to get more honey from Ling than from any other plants; but what is produced from it has a reddish cast, and is therefore not so much valued.
Common Heath, or Ling. Erica vulgaris.—
Dead or spotted Arsmart. P. Persicaria. A.
Herb Paris, One Berry. Paris quadrifolia. P.

207.Bottle Campion. This plant is common with us on the borders of corn-fields, and Gunner says it is among the most acceptable herbs to cows. Its cultivation has on this ac∣count been recommended in foreign publications.
White and Red Campion. Lychnis dioica. P.
Marsh Mouse-ear Chickweed. C. aquaticum. P.
Meadow Pink. Lychnis Flos Cuculi. P.—
Stone Crop: Wall Pepper. S. acre. P.—
White-flowered Stone Crop. S. album. P.—
Purple spiked Loosestrife. Lythrum Salicaria. P.
In meadows, pastures, and by way sides. 6, 7.
In woods and hedges, in the North. 7, 8.
On mountains and heaths, in the North. 4, 5.
On turfy boggy grounds, in the North. 5.
In shady thick woods, and about springs. 4.
In and about rivers and ditches. 6, 7.
In meadows, waste places, corn fields, &c. 8, 9.
In and about ditches and moist places. 7, 8.
By the way sides, waste places, very common. 6, 9.
In woods and groves, in the North. 6, 7.
On bogs and wet turfy grounds, in the North. 4.
On heaths and dry pastures, not common. 6, 7.
In corn fields and gravelly grounds. 8.
On fallow lands, and among corn. 7.
208.White and Red Campion. The same author relates that this plant is thought by some of the peasants in Norway to cause staling of blood in the horned cattle.
In woods, and about hedges, every where. 5—7.
Every where in moist and shady places.
Dry sandy grounds, and on the sea coasts. 6, 7.
211.Corn Spurrey. This plant has been cultivated as food for cattle, and is thought by some writers on agriculture to deserve more notice than has hitherto been paid to it.
Among corn, and on fallow ground. 8.
In meadows and pastures, very common. 5.
In moist places about ditches and rivers. 7.
In woods, and under shady hedges. 4.
About hedges, old walls, and in pastures. 8.
On walls, on rocks and mountains. 6.
In kitchen gardens, and sometimes in corn fields. 7.
By the banks of rivers and lakes. 7.
229.Common Dropwort. Swine are extremely fond of the roots of this plant, and will make great devastation in pastures where they find it.
Common Briar, or Dog Rose. Rosa Canina.
The Wood Strawberry. Fragaria vesca. P.

237.Silver Weed. The same animals are not less fond of the roots of this plant, which have somewhat the taste of parsnips; and Ray informs us that they were formerly eaten in this country, as they still are in less happy climates. Gunner.
240.Tormentil. The roots of Tormentil being an excellent astringent, are used by the farmersi n Holland as a remedy against the staling of blood among their cattle.
Purple Marsh Cinquefoil. Comarum palustre. P.
Avens: Herb Bennet. Geum urbanum. P.—
243.Yellow Water Lilly. It is remarkable that scarcely any animals, except bogs, will touch this plant, and they will eat both roots and leaves, and fatten by their use. Flor. Oeconomic.
Yellow Water Lilly. Nymphaea lutea. P.—
White Water Lilly. N. alba. P.—
Long rough-headed Poppy. P. Argemone. A.
Sweet Wood Crowsoot. R. auricomus. P.—
In waste places in chalky grounds. 6.
About hedges and the borders of fields. 6.
In woods and hedges, not common. 5.
In woods and hedges, not common. 4.
In moist meadows, and by rivers and brooks. 6—8.
In heaths, among furze, in gravelly soil. 6.
In hedges every where, and thickets. 5—9.
With the former in moist places. 6, 7.
By the road sides; in low pastures. 6—8.
In like places with the foregoing. 6.
In dry woods and pastures, common. 6, 7.
In hedges, woods, and thickets, common. 6—8.
With the foregoing, but not so common. 7.
248.Herb Cbristopher. This is one of the poisonous herbs to cattle, but is happily scarce in England, and not found elsewhere than in woods.

249.The leaves of the Lime Tree are in some parts of Europe laid up as fodder for sheep and goats. Bees get their finest honey from these trees. Cows are fond of the leaves, but they are said to vitiate the milk.
On dry, and particularly chalky downs. 7.

255.Wood Anemone. Horned cattle, when removed from higher grounds into woods and woody pasturage, frequently eat this herb, and many observations have proved that it causes the bloody flux among them. Lin. Gunner.
In wet pastures, and by river sides. 6, 7.
In meadows and pastures every where. 4.

260.Crowfeet, or Butter Cups. Scarcely any of these plants are relished by the cows or horses, from their biting taste; the Round-leaved Water Crowfoot, the Upright Meadow Crowfoot, and particularly the Various-leaved Crowfoot, are constantly left un∣touched, while growing. The acrimony in these plants appears to be dissipated in the hay, into which they often enter in a large proportion.
Round-leaved Water Crowfoot. Ranunculus sceleratus. A.—
Upright Meadow Crowfoot. R. acris. P.—

265.Marsh Marigold. It has been conjectured that the yellowness of the butter is in many places owing to the cattle having fed on the large yellow flowers of this plant; which is however a great error, as cows do not touch the plant, although they pare the ground around it.
Great wild Basil. Clinopodium vulgare. P.—

273.Mints. All Mints are thought to have the property of retarding or prevent∣ing the curdling of milk. Hence it is that in some places, towards the latter end of the year, when herbage is scarce, and the cows are necessitated to eat these plants in more con∣siderable quantities, the dairy-woman has difficulty to make her cheese.
White Dead Nettle. Lamium album. P.—
Least Toad Flax. A. minus. A.—
Yellow Rattle, or Cock's-comb. Rhinanthus Crista Galli. A.—
Crested Cow wheat. Melampyrum cristatum. A.
In meadows and pastures every where. 5, 6.
In mountainous pastures, in the North. 5, 6.
In moist meadows and pastures, and woods. 5, 6.
About hedges, and in dry pastures. 7.
On arable land and corn grounds. 8, 9.
In wate y places, and by rivers, ponds, &c.
Under shady hedge, and in woods. 5, 6.
In waste places and by hedges, every where. 7.
On arable land, dry pastures, and waste places.
By hedges, and on upland pastures. 7.
On heaths, and in woods, common. 7, 8.
280.Hedge Nettle. Horses abominate this plant. Cows, notwithstanding its foetid smell, will eat it, and Gunner says it undoubtedly increases their milk greatly.
In hedges and woods every where. 7, 8.
281.Clowns Alheal. The roots of this plant are among the acceptable food of swine: they are indeed sapid enough to have supplied in some seasons the want of bread to the hu∣man species.
In watery places, and about rivers. 8.
On arable grounds, and borders of fields. 8.
About hedges, and in waste places. 5, 6.
In waste places, and on arable land. 5.
In meadows and pastures every where. 8.
About hedges, and dry barren pastures. 7.
On arable land, and among corn. 6—9.

293.Louseworts. These plants are very noxious to cattle, when through penury, or other causes, they are induced to eat them. Gunner affirms, that it is very common for cattle, that are removed into pastures where the Marsh Lousewort abounds, to die suddenly from staling of blood. He observes, that such as are bred where it is plentiful, either do not eat it, or are not hurt by it. It is too common with us.
In boggy marshy meadows and heaths. 6, 7.
In moist and marshy meadows and pastures. 6.

296.Cow-wheat. Cows are extravagantly fond of this plant, and the richness, as well as yellowness, of the butter, in some places, is with great reason attributed to the abundance of this plant in the pastures, Flor. Lap. No 240.
Shepherds Purse. T. Bursa Pastoris. A.—
Narrow-leaved wild Cress. L. ruderale. A.
Gold of Pleasure. Myagrum sativum. A.—
Great Tower Mustard. Turritis glabra. A.
Wild Navew, or Rape. Brassica Napus. B.
Wild Mustard, or Charlock. Sinapis arvensis. A.
Winter Cresses, or Rocket. E. Barbarea.—
Jack by the Hedge: Sauce alone. E. Alliaria. P.
322.Charlocks. The pests of our corn-fields, and which have been thought to give a most unwholesome quality to bread when the seeds abound in grain.
White and Yellow flowered Charlock. Ra∣phanus Raphanistrum. A.—
Crow foot Cranes bill. Geranium pratense. P.

326.
Herb Robert. This plant is in great reputation with some farmers, on account of its prevailing virtues against staling of blood, and the bloody flux in cattle: in which cases it is said to be the best among a great variety of means commonly used upon such occasions.
Diadelphous Plants. A general view of this class shews at once how very acceptable they are to almost all cattle. Cows and sheep refused none, and horses not more than three out of the whole number with which they were tried. They afford the richest food for cattle, and are cultivated in divers parts of Europe with all possible attention. With us the Com∣mon Purple Tref il, or Clover, is mostly sown. Lately some trials have been made with the Saint Foin, 339, and some have thought it answers better than Clover. I say nothing of the exotic Lucern.
Among these Plants, the Kidney Vetch, 327, is particularly acceptable to sheep, insomuch that separate cultivation of it has been recommended; but it will not succeed well except on chalky grounds.
Common Dove's▪foot Cranes-bill. G. molle. A.
In meadows and pastures, very common. 8, 9.
On the borders of fields, and on arable ground, 8, 9.
In shady places at the foot of mountains: rare.
On mole hills, in dry pastures. 4.

On the borders of fields, and on arable land: rare. 7.

In ditches and watery places, very common.

The pest of corn fields in England. 6, 7.

With the foregoing, and about hedges, common, 5, 6.

On upland pastures and heaths, common. 5, 6.
On coarse pastures, and the borders of fields.
In meadows, pastures, and about hedges.
Wood Pease; Heath Pease. Orobus tuberosus. P.
St. Foin; Cockshead. Hedysarum Onobrichis. P.
Narrow-leaved Everlasting Pea. Lathyrus sylvestris. P.—
341.Common Yellow Vetchling. Uncommonly grateful to cattle; as is also the
Common Yellow Vetchling. L. pratensis. P.
Common Vetch, or Tare. Vicia sativa. A.—
Tufted Wood Vetch. V. sylvatica. P.—
345.Common tufted Vetch. Both these are very common in our best meadows and pastures.
Common tufted Vetch. V. Cracca. P.—
Smooth-podded Tine Tare. Ervum tetra∣spermum. A.—
Hairy podded Tine Tare. E. hirsutum. A.

350.
White Trefoil. Wherever this plant occurs spontaneously, and abounds, it is always considered as an indication of the goodness of the soil; and this is a thing well known to all farmers.
The richness of all meadows and pastures is naturally owing to their abounding princi∣pally with the Trefoils, and others of the same class, with a due mixture of the more ac∣ceptable Grasses.
Honeysuckle Tresoil, or Clover. T. pratense.
Lesser Hop Trefoil. T. procumbens. P.—
Yellow Lucern, or Medick. Medicago falcata.
Rest-harrow, or Cammock. Ononis arvensis. P.
St. John's Wort. H. perforatum. P.—
Hairy St. John's Wort. H. hirsutum. P.—
Hawkweed with bitter roots. L. autumnale. P.
Tree, or Corn Sowthistle. S. arvensis. P.—
Ivy-leaved wild Lettuce. Phrenanthes mura∣lis. P.—
Wild Succory, or Endive. Cichorium Intybus. B.
In woods; and sometimes in meadows, &c. 5.

Cultivated: and often wild in corn fields.

On tilled grounds, and among corn. 6.
In meadows, pastures, woods, every where. 7, 8.
The pride of meadows and pastures. 5—9.
In hedges, and in the borders of corn fields. 6, 7.
On the borders of fields, not common. 7.

356.Melilot Trefoil. This plant, which is exceedingly common, is notwithstanding much less agreeable to cattle than the rest of the Trefoils. This observation occurred to Plukenet, who called it Medica pratensis lutea non grata jumentis; and Linnaeus has informed us particularly that future observations have confirmed the remark.

357.Rest-harrow, or Cammock. A decoction of this plant has been much recommended to horses labouring under a stoppage of urine. It is the pest of some corn-fields; but in its younger state, before the plant has acquired its thorns, is a most acceptable herb to sheep.
In moist hedges, and the banks of brooks.
In hedges and bushes, very common. 7.
In meadows and pastures, every where. 4—6.
In mountainous pastures: scarce in England. 7.
366.Creeping Mouse-ear. Very common on our dry pastures, and sometimes eaten by sheep; to which animals Ray says it is very hurtful from its powerful astringent quality.
On uplands and dry pastures, common. 5.
In meadows and pastures, very common. 6—9.
In manured grounds, corn fields, waste places.
In corn fields and about hedges. 7.
In hedges and waste places, kitchen gardens. 6, 7.
On the borders of corn fields. 7, 8.
By the way sides, waste places, &c. 7, 8.
Dwarf Carline Thistle. C. acaulis. P.—
Soft or gentle Thistle. C. beterophyllus.—
Thistle upon Thistle. C. crispus. A.—
Corn Saw-wort, or Way Thistle. S. arvensis. P.
Trifid Water Hemp Agrimony. Bidens tri∣partita. A.—
Whole-leaved Water Hemp Agrimony. B. cernua. A.—
Dutch, or Hemp Agrimony. Eupatorium cannabinum. P.—
Golden Rod. Solidago Virga aurea. P.—
406.Corn Marigold. This plant infests the corn-fields in many parts of Europe, and in Denmark there was a law enforcing the farmers to rid their fields of it.
407.Great Daisie. Very common in our pastures, but unacceptable to cows; neither is the common Daisie relished by them.
Sneeze-wort: Goose tongue. A. Ptarmica. P.
417.Common Knapweed. A harsh and ungrateful plant to cows and sheep, but impossible extirpated, thh very common in our best meadows and pastures.
B ue Bottle. C. Cyanus. A.—
Hairy Sheeps Scabious. Jasione montana. A.
Panfies; Hearts Eafe. V. tricolor. A.—
In waste places: and on fallow grounds. .
Waste places, about hedges; fallow lands.
On uplands and fallow grounds abundantly.
On day pastures: heaths and downs. 7.
In marshy pastures, not very common.
In marshy pastures, and in woods. 7.
By the way sides, and on fallow grounds.
In marshy grounds, and about waters. 7, 8.
On high pastures in the North, and by rivers in the South. 8.
About hedges, corn fields, and wastes. 8.
In waste places, and by road sides. 8, 9.
On dry upland pastures in the North. 5.
In watery places, and where water has stagnated. 8.
In moist waste places, and among corn. 3.
In moist meadows by rivers and brooks. 3, 4.
In woods, hedges, and among furze, on heaths.

In manured waste grounds every where.
On upland dry pastures, among bushes.

In moist places, and where water has stagnated.
In meadows and pastures, every where. 5.
In and about corn fields: farm yards.
In waste places, and about hedges. 6.

419.
Cudweed, so called because husbandmen formerly gave it to cattle that did not rumi∣nate freely.
A general view of the syngenesious class, shews at once the vast difference between this and the diadelphous; of the former we see great numbers are rejected by cows, and by sheep more particularly.
By the way sides, and in dry pastures. 6, 7.
Touch me not. Impatiens noli me tangere. A.
Male Orchis Salep. Orchis majula. P.—
Male handed Orchis. O. latifolia. P.—
Red handed Orchis. O. conosea. B.—
Female handed Orchis. O. maculata. P.—

434.Grass Wrack. Besides the utility of this plant as an excellent manure in certain places, and for making mounds or walls (which will stand, when well constructed, for a vast number of years) cows and horses will frequently leave their pastures to feed in the sea∣water itself upon this plant. Gunner refers to an instance of some horned cattle that were very well sustained, through a severe winter, by the help of this plant only. Its utility for mounds against the encroachment of the sea, in apt situations, is well known, and there are instances of its having stood in this way for upwards of eighty years.
Great brown Carex or Sedge. C. acuta. P.
Feathered Water Milfoil. Myriophyllum spi¦catum. P.—
Common Fir, or Pitch Tree. P. Abies.—
Sweet Willow Dutch Myrtle. Myrica Gale.
In hedges and ditches; in woods. 3.
In moist shady places in the North. 8.
In meadows and pastures; among bushes. 5.
In moist meadows and pastures, common.
In moist meadows and pastures, and woods. 6.
In the shallow salt waters abundantly.
435.Sedges are coarse and unwholesome food for those cattle that are obliged to eat them, and are said sometimes to occasion great flatulence, and disorder.
In watery places, and by the banks of rivers. 7.
In watery places, and about rivers. 6.
Common in watery places about rivers, &c.
In standing and slow running waters. 7.
In like places with the foregoing. 7, 8.
442.Nettles are eaten by sheep and cows, while the plants are young.
In waste grounds, and arable land. 8.
In like places with the former. 7.
In waters, and about ditches and rivers. 6.
On downs, especially in a chalky soil. 7.
The pride and glory of our woods. 4.
In hedges, woods, and thickets, common. 5.
Frequent in the North of England. 4.
By waters, and in woods and hedges. 4.
458.Herbaceous Willow. Acceptable to cows and horses. Gunner says the latter will leave grass to feed upon it.
On the sea coast, not common. 4.
About rivers, and in watery places. 3.
Asp, or trembling Poplar. Populus tremula.
467.Dogs Mercury is absolutely poisonous to sheep, which will sometimes eat it. Our own, observations, many times repeated, have taught us that horses will not touch it.
469.Black Bryony. This is not a Swedish plant; it is common in our hedges, but horses refuse it.

471.Yew Tree. That the Yew is poisonous to horned cattle and horses, is proved be∣yond all doubt. Several cases of its fatal effects have fallen under our own knowledge. A memorable one occurs also in the Phil. Trans. vol. xlvii. p. 195.
477.Corn Horse-tail is said to be very noxious to horned cattle and sheep, both by Gunner and others; and Loeselius says it brings on abortion, if pregnant ewes eat it.
Female Fern, or Brakes. Pteris aquilina.—
Common Male Fern. P. Filix mas.—
Common Fucus, or Sea Oak. F. vesiculosus.—
In woods, particularly in boggy soils.
In woods and thickets, and under hedges, 4, 5.
On heaths and mountains in the North.
About dunghills; and on the sea shores. 8, 9.
In waste places, and about hedges. 8.
On mountainous boggy places in the North. 4, 5.

478.Wood Horse-tail. Horses are extremely fond of this, and where it is abundant, as is the case in some of the northern parts of Europe, hay of this alone is made for their use; as also of the River Horse-tail, which the cows like, and it is thought to encrease their milk.
In watery places, and about rivers. 5.
In woods, and on heaths, very common.
On old walls, and stumps of trees.
In woods, hedges, and shady lanes.
In rocky places in the North.
In shady, stony boggy places under hedges.
488.Fucus. All these Fucuses are eaten by cows; but Gunner says the Thread Fucus is not only acceptable to them, but very wholesome.

DIV1.HEAD: A CATALOGUE OF THE WRITINGS and PUBLICATIONS of LINNAEUS: With References to the Pages in which they are mentioned in this Volume.

ITEM.HI: SYSTEMA NATURAE sive Regna tria Naturae systematice proposita, per Classes, Ordi∣nes Genera & Species.

LIST.LABEL: Edition 1. Lugd. Bat. fol. maxim. 1735.—Page 16.
LIST.ITEM: This is comprized in twelve pages; and is the out∣lines only of the succeeding editions. The Swedish names are annexed.
LIST.LABEL: 2. Holm. 8vo. page 80. 1740.
LIST.ITEM: Revised and augmented by LINNAEUS himself, with the addition of the generical characters, and names to the subjects of the animal kingdom.
LIST.LABEL: 3. Halae. 4to. oblong. p. 70. 1740.
LIST.ITEM: By J. Langen, in Latin and German.
LIST.LABEL: 4. Parisiis. 8vo. p. 108. tab. 1. 1744.
LIST.ITEM: By Bernard Jussieu; with the addition of the French names; otherwise the same as the second edition.
LIST.LABEL: 5. Halae. 8vo. p. 88. 1747.
LIST.ITEM: By M. G. Agnethler. With the German names; other∣wise the same as the second edition.
LIST.LABEL: 6. Holmiae. 8vo. p. 232. tab. 8. 1748.—Page 60.
LIST.ITEM: Embellished with a print of the Author. Aug∣mented by the introduction of the essential characters of the genera of plants; and by the addition of the species to the animal and fossil kingdoms.
LIST.LABEL: 7. Lipsiae. 8vo. p. 232. tab. 8. 1748.
LIST.ITEM: By a Bookseller; with the German names.
LIST.LABEL: 8. Holm. 8vo. p. 136. 1753.
LIST.ITEM: In the Swedish language. The vegetable kingdom by Haartman; the fossil by Moller.
LIST.LABEL: 9. Lugd. Bat. 8vo. p. 228. t. 8. 60. 1756—54.
LIST.ITEM: By Dr. Gronovius, with a few additions to the ani∣mal kingdom; otherwise copied from No 6. This edition was also printed at Lucca, in 1758.
LIST.LABEL: 10. Holm. 8vo. 2 tom. 1758.—60.

LIST.ITEM: Tom. 1. p. 821. Animal kingdom. Enlarged by the addition of the synonyms.
Tom. 2. p. 560. Vegetable kingdom. Enlarged by the addition of the species under each genus.

LIST.LABEL: 11. Lipsiae.
12. Holm. 8vo. 3 tom. 1766, 1767, 1768.
Vindob. 8vo. 3 tom. 1, 1767. 2, 3, 1770.
LIST.ITEM: From the foregoing; the pages corresponding.
LIST.LABEL: 13. Gottingae et Gothae. 8vo. 1774. Page 210.
LIST.ITEM: Tom. 2. only, by Dr. Murray, with Linnaeus's ad∣ditions and emendations.

ITEM.HI: HYPOTHESIS NOVA de febrium intermitten∣tium causa.

LIST.ITEM: Also, in the first volume of the Amoenitates Acade∣micae, printed at Leyden, 1749.—

COROLLARIUM GENERUM: et METHODUS SEXUALIS.
Lugd. Bat. 8vo. 1737.—21.

ITEM.HI: CRITICA BOTANICA: cui accedit Browallii discursus, de introducenda in scholas his∣toriae naturalis lectione.

LIST.ITEM: In Latin: with the two succeeding, in the Amoe∣nitates Academ. vol. ii. 1751.—31.
